Ah, the d10! While you aren't actually a true regular polyhedron, you are the only die that makes logical sense--metrically speaking. Chances are, others see you as over-analytical or a goody-goody. While that may be true, you also have a gift for patience and tolerance. Growing up you probably had a calculator wristwatch that you never really needed to use (since you were faster on your own), and you probably aced all your classes (except for gym). You use the metric system almost exclusively, but are able to quickly convert in mid-conversation for the sake of your backwards Imperalist friends. You've coded in at least two different programming languages, and have created more original gaming systems than you'll ever admit. You're generally not a show-off, but you do take pride in being called either a geek or a nerd.

Take the quiz at dicepool.com

Someone emailed this to me, I thought it was worth posting...

As I'm matured....

  • I've learned that you cannot make someone love you. All you can do is stalk them and hope they panic and give in.
  • I've learned that one good turn gets most of the blankets.
  • I've learned that no matter how much I care, some people are just jackasses.
  • I've learned that it takes years to build up trust, and it only takes suspicion, not proof, to destroy it.
  • I've learned that whatever hits the fan will not be evenly distributed.
  • I've learned that you shouldn't compare yourself to others - they are more screwed up than you think.
  • I've learned that depression is merely anger without enthusiasm.
  • I've learned that it is not what you wear; it is how you take it off.
  • I've learned that you can keep vomiting long after you think you're finished.
  • I've learned to not sweat the petty things, and not pet the sweaty things.
  • I've learned that ex's are like fungus, and keep coming back.
  • I've learned age is a very high price to pay for maturity.
  • I've learned that I don't suffer from insanity, I enjoy it.
  • I've learned that we are responsible for what we do, unless we are celebrities.
  • I've learned that artificial intelligence is no match for natural stupidity.
  • I've learned that 99% of the time when something isn't working in your house, one of your kids did it.
  • I've learned that there is a fine line between genius and insanity.
  • I've learned that the people you care most about in life are taken from you too soon and all the less important ones just never go away. And the real pains in the ass are permanent.

Question of the Day: Why is it that every morning, when I take my first bite of whatever I am having for breakfast, I sneeze?

I was in subway the other day, and this guy was getting all upset at the poor subway clerk, because they would not redeem his subway coupon for a Willowtree chickens salad sandwich. I mean come on; EVERYONE knows that Willowtree is a local brand name, and not a subway product. Some people!

I just got the email that the PBeM game I was in is canceled. Turns out the guy running it does not have enough time, which is understandable.

Oh well, these things happen. But hey, after I get settled in to the new house, maybe I will start one of my own, and maybe Lord Azagol will make his return there!

Anyhow, I went ahead and unlocked all my posts related to the campaign (not that there are many), since there is no point in hiding them anymore. :o)

You are Megatron. You don't know the meaning of the
word compassion. You would stab your own mother
if she so much as looked at you in a way you
didn't like. Death, destruction, and domination
are your jobs and your hobbies are probably
worse. On a plus side, no one can find a weak
circuit in your mainframe. Rock on with your
obsessively evil self.

A Great Big Linux Update

I know you have all been sitting at the edge of your seats waiting to know what has happened to my Linux efforts. Or maybe not. In either case, here it is :o) Its a three day weekend, so that means one thing,.. I get to work on some of my geek-projects! No Sound, what did you say!? So I figured out the problem with my sound card. Now, here is a great troubleshooting tip for everyone, make sure the get this down on paper, because this is going to get technical, and you will probably need it some day. If you are not getting sound, plug in your speakers. Problem Status: Solved Whole lot of trouble Well, the computer I used is old, and the case is not in good shape. There is a missing back plate, which is bad because a lot of dust, or even bugs (the real kind) could get in there and cause all sorts of problems. Well, I don't have any spare covers (Damn things are always in my way, until I need one). So I ran to CompUSA while we were at the laundry mat waiting for our cloths to dry, and picked up a Mad Dog PCI cooling fan for $8.99. Now the whole is covered and my machine gets some extra cooling. Problem Status: Solved Printer not ummm... printing OK, so I started off trying to network the Linux box to the printer on my windows machine. But for some reason I was not able to get it to detect the printer. So I did a LOT of research and found that a lot of people said that Windows 98 Home Edition did not come with some of the networking drivers needed to share printers under some situation. So I figure, heck, I'll just put the printer on the Linux machine, and let the windows machine network to it. I've read that my printer works perfectly with Linux (they even claimed that I would get better print quality). So I move the printer over, and run through the setup wizard. It had my printer listed, GREAT. I figured I was home free. But no, the darn thing wont print. If I change the drivers to a printer driver that is for a similar model, it prints out gibberish, so I know the printer is visible to the OS. I tried a whole bunch of other things too, with no success. Well, I broke down and went to ArkLinux website and posted in the forums for some help. Problem Status: In Progress Mail-room jumble So my kMail (Linux's standard email client) has been updated to read my hotmail account. This is very cool, because I like how kMail works, and I hate web-mail. But kMail seems to have trouble with some times of email meta data. When this happens the subjects, date, and sender information is not detected, and there is a bunch of gibberish added the the header of the email (this is actually the meta data itself, so its not really gibberish, but its annoying none-the-less). I have found an article that explains how to update kMail to read this type of email header, but I am too lazy to do it right now, so I book marked it and will do it later. Problem Status: Waiting (for me to stop being lazy) Thats it. Once I get those last few issues resolved, i believe my Linux machine will be 100% up-and-running.

My Future Linux Projects

BTCC While surfing around for KDE updates, I found that there is a cool open source project to create a Linux/Windows based Battletech PC game. Well I am a huge Battletech fan, so I tried installing it. Did work though, and since I had other things to take care of I tabled it for now. But I would like o check this out, and heck, maybe if they have an opening I will volunteer my services to help complete the project. I would like to learn to code in Python anyhow. Battletech: Total Control Emulate Windows IOK, so at this point, I have an awesome machine, running a 100% free system. But I have a lot of windows games that I don't want want to loose access to. So I will eventually look into installing a windows emulator so that I can play these games. My first stop: TransGaming Serve it up! The PBeM (Play By Email) game I just joined has brought back memories of my Battletech PBeM days. So I was thinking that after this game has finished, I might try my hand at running my own D&D or Battletech PBeM game. What does this have to do with my Linux efforts? I am thinking about hosting a PHP/MySQL based site on this machine that would host the forum, resources, and tools of the game. Jukebox Baby! I saw this really cool book in the book store the other day. It was called Linux Toys, and had ideas for all sorts of cool projects you could do with spare hardware and Linux. One idea was to build a Jukebox. So if I can find one of those small cube-like cases that can house my spare ATX motherboard, I might try this out. It would work like this. any CD you put in automatically rips to the local CD DB. I would install a wireless network PCI card ($25 from newegg.com), and allow remote access to it from any other machine on the network. I put (hide) this small cube in the living room and hook it into the stereo (no monitor/mouse/keyboard of course, so it would just be the cube). Then I can control the play list form any PC in the house. It would be awesome for parties and stuff (Don't laugh, it could happen).

The new PBeM game I am in has not started yet, but I purchased my units and sent some more basic info, so hopfully it will start soon. But in the meantime, I have created a new pic for LJ for my posts as Lord Azagol.
